unnormalised: Alright folks, buckle up, because this blog is about to get real… real time-y! We’re diving headfirst into the thrilling world of Indian sports schedules. And let me tell you, trying to keep track of everything is more chaotic than a Delhi traffic jam at 5 PM!
normalised: Alright folks, buckle up, because this blog is about to get real… real time-y! We are diving headfirst into the thrilling world of Indian sports schedules. And let me tell you, trying to keep track of everything is more chaotic than a Delhi traffic jam at five P-M!

unnormalised: First off, let's talk cricket. Because, duh. The IPL, starting typically around 03/25 every year, is a national holiday disguised as a sporting event. For, like, 2 months straight. My office productivity takes a nosedive faster than a Pakistani batting order after lunch. Trying to schedule a meeting during a crucial match? Forget about it. Everyone’s suddenly “unavailable” between 8 PM and 11:30 PM.
normalised: First off, let us talk cricket. Because, duh. The I-P-L, starting typically around twenty fifth March every year, is a national holiday disguised as a sporting event. For, like, two months straight. My office productivity takes a nosedive faster than a Pakistani batting order after lunch. Trying to schedule a meeting during a crucial match? Forget about it. Everyone is suddenly “unavailable” between eight P-M and eleven thirty P-M.

unnormalised: And the matches! Oh, the matches. They’re scheduled with the precision of a Swiss watch… that’s been dropped down a flight of stairs. Seriously, the schedule changes more often than my auto-rickshaw driver changes his price after seeing my suitcase. One day it’s 4 PM, the next it’s 7:30 PM. Keep up, folks!

Seriously, the schedule changes more often than my auto-rickshaw driver changes his price after seeing my suitcase. One day it is four P-M, the next it is seven thirty P-M. Keep up, folks!

unnormalised: Then we have the Pro Kabaddi League, another spectacle. It usually kicks off around mid-July and stretches till Oct end. Now, I personally love kabaddi, but trying to remember which team is playing which on 08/16 at 9 PM is a workout for my brain. Especially when you are trying to watch it at the same time!

unnormalised: Speaking of workouts, let's not forget the Indian Super League (ISL), for football fans. They usually start around Oct/Nov and last until March. Trying to convince my friends to watch it instead of cricket is like trying to get Rahul Gandhi to lead a successful election campaign – nearly impossible. But if they ever get on board and want to watch games, they will need to know it is between 7:30 PM-9:30 PM.

unnormalised: And then, my personal favorite, the Badminton scene. You have to keep track of PV Sindhu and Lakshya Sen playing at like 2:15 AM IST during the All England Open. It’s like, who even schedules these things? Are they trying to give us all insomnia? But, I get it- International competitions have their time zones.

unnormalised: And of course, every four years, we have the Commonwealth Games and the Asian Games. Good luck figuring out which event is on what day and what time. My strategy? Just record everything and watch it later… much, much later. Preferably after a large cup of chai and a good nap.

unnormalised: Let’s not forget those random friendly matches, too! I mean, sure, they're "friendly", but the schedules are anything but. They sneak up on you like a surprise exam in college. You're just minding your own business, and BAM! India vs. some country you’ve never heard of, at 3:30 AM. Thanks, I hate it.

unnormalised: So, how do we navigate this scheduling nightmare? Well, you could hire a personal assistant… or just accept the fact that you’re going to miss some stuff. Embrace the chaos, my friends. It’s the Indian way!

unnormalised: In conclusion, following Indian sports schedules is like trying to understand the rules of cricket – confusing, often frustrating, but ultimately, strangely rewarding. Just remember to set your alarms, stock up on snacks, and be prepared for anything… especially unexpected schedule changes. Good luck, and may the odds (and the TV remote) be ever in your favor! And never plan any important work between Sept-2024 to Oct-2024 because there are going to be a LOT of matches!
